subject: Economics
title: David Ricardo: Comparative Advantage Explained
description: Learn David Ricardo: Comparative Advantage Explained in one minute.

hook.text: Even if you're better at everything than your neighbor, you should still specialize. David Ricardo proved why in 1817.

buildup.text: Ricardo used England (cloth) and Portugal (wine) as examples.

discovery.text: Comparative advantage: specialize in what you do relatively best and trade for the rest.

twist.text: Ricardo was a self-made stock trader worth $100 million (today's value) who bought a seat in Parliament to push free.

climax.text: Comparative advantage is the foundation of all international trade.

punchline.text: Even the best at everything benefits from not doing everything.

quiz.question: What does comparative advantage mean?
options: The country with the most resources wins
Nations benefit by specializing in what they produce relatively most efficiently and trading
Only rich countries benefit from trade
